abstractText: A Nepalese palm-leaf manuscript of the Cāndravyākaraṇa of the Buddhist grammarian Candragomin (probably 5th c. CE) with its most widespread and best known commentary, the Cāndravyākaraṇavṛtti, for a long time believed to be the work of Candragomin himself, but now generally attributed (Dash 1986; Oberlies 1989) to an author called Dharmadāsa who probably flourished in the 6th c. CE, but of whom nothing else is known. The manuscript contains the whole fourth section (pāda, literally “quarter”) of the fifth chapter (adhyāya), which comprises 176 rules. However, due to the very poor condition of f. 18v, only one of the final four rules, namely 5.4.175, āne mug ataḥ, is still legible, though barely, on line 4. A few words from the commentary on the final sūtra, 5.4.176, āsīnaḥ, can also be identified, followed by a sequence of much faded akṣaras that might be the final rubric either of the section or of the whole chapter five. The manuscript is not very accurate and even the text of the sūtras shows numerous spelling mistakes.
